attributes.action: Pressure Japan to abandon plans to discharge contaminated water into the sea
attributes.background: The UK Government must put pressure, including using its influence in the UN, on the Japanese Government to reverse their decision of 13 April 2021 to discharge water contaminated with radioactive material from the Fukushima nuclear power plant into the sea.
attributes.additional_details:
Protect the sea!
Protect our environment!

departments.name: Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office

attributes.action: Require a license to order Nitrous Oxide canisters.
attributes.background: Discuss the issues surround the use of Nitrous Oxide for recreational purposes. It is highly dangerous and incredibly cheap and accessible. There needs to be some way to regulate the purchases of these canisters. As they are for kitchen use, businesses should require a license to purchase them.
attributes.additional_details:
Our local town is covered in small canisters/balloons from where people have been using these for a quick high and leaving their rubbish around. Not only is this bad for the environment, but it’s also a highly dangerous drug which is now becoming a major issue. 

We need to make these products harder to access. Businesses who use these regularly should require a license to purchase them, and all other purchases of these should be illegal.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban the development of Wind Farms within AONBs and National Parks in England
attributes.background: We want a ban to all Wind Farm developments within the environmentally designated AONBs and National Parks. This is due to the onshore wind farms having too much of an impact in terms of Sustainable Development
attributes.additional_details: We must get the principles of Sustainable Development embedded in decision making. Large private owned and public listed companies are exploiting our natural environment. This is wrong and is designed purely for profit. The UK Government should also encourage the devolved administrations to implement similar bans in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Action on Non Exhaust Emissions
attributes.background: The government should adopt as legally binding the World Health Organisation guideline levels  for PM2.5 of 10µg/m³ as an annual mean threshold by 2030.
attributes.additional_details:
The Environment Bill must include legislation on non-exhaust emissions - these are particles from tyres, the road surface and plasticisers. Also known as PM2.5, the major source of these invisible microparticulate
Environmentally friendly and sustainable transport solutions must be found for our busy towns and cities which should include light rail systems.
Parliament should recognise and support in law efforts to clean up the air in our towns and cities.
This should include the provision of a new local transport infrastructure fund to enable transport authorities to develop sustainable clean alternatives including light rail.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Heavy tax and public awareness on all 'Not Yet Recycled' plastics
attributes.background: Heavily tax all 'Not Yet Recycled' plastics and enforce a packaging consumer awareness campaign similar to that on tobacco products that highlights the damage the plastic product does to the environment over others.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Banning of Fipronil and Imidacloprid in flea treatments for dogs
attributes.background: To ban the use of Fipronil and Imidacloprid products in the treatment of dogs and cats for the prevention of fleas and ticks.   They have been found to enter our rivers and waterways when the bedding of dogs and cats are washed with the effluent entering the sewerage system and thence rivers.
attributes.additional_details: The use of Fipronil and Imidacloprid in products designed to prevent the infestation of dogs and cats with fleas and ticks has been found to be extremely detrimental to insect life in our rivers.  Several millions of animals are treated many times a year.  The products degrade to compounds that are more persistent in the environment.  Fipronil and its toxic breakdown products have been present in nearly all freshwater samples tested.  This is of extreme concern for the insect life in our rivers.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase fixed penalty fines for littering
attributes.background: Penalties need to be increased to a level which shows that the authorities and society will no longer tolerate this antisocial, selfish behaviour, detrimental to the environment.
attributes.additional_details:
We have seen scenes across England of littered strewn parks, nature reserves, beaches and open spaces recently. Litter can have an effect on residents, people’s health, the economy, business, tourism, on crime and anti-social behaviour, and of course, on the environment.
 
'A Green Future: Our 25 Year Plan to Improve the Environment', sets out what the Government will do to improve the environment within a generation. Increasing consequences for littering could have an immediate positive environmental effect.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Prioritise pregnant women and their birth partners for Covid-19 vaccination
attributes.background: The approved vaccines should be offered to pregnant women AND their birth partner regardless of age or health status. As lockdown eases, the potential risk of a birth partner catching Covid-19 and therefore missing the birth of a child increases: The impact of this could be irreversibly devastating.
attributes.additional_details: Pregnant women have long been advised by the RCOG that their health risk increases in third trimester. Now that the Moderna and Pfizer vaccines have been approved for pregnant women, they should be offered the vaccine regardless of their age group as all pregnant women have to attend various appointments in higher risk hospital environments. This should be extended to birth partners at the same time, to both protect the mother and ensure that they do not risk missing a crucial life event.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Keep retained EU environmental laws until equal or stronger UK laws introduced
attributes.background: The Retained EU Law (Revocation & Reform) Bill will remove EU-derived law protecting air, water, wildlife, land and waste in 2023. We want these laws to be retained until replacement legislation is passed which delivers equal or stronger protection for nature than retained EU law.
attributes.additional_details: UK governments in the past decade have variously promised to be "the greenest government ever" and "to be the first generation that leaves the environment in a better state than that in which we inherited it". But the EU Law Bill risks creating a "gun-at-the-head" deadline for replacing retained EU law, rather than removing retained laws when Parliament has formulated and passed equal or stronger UK law. We believe spending valuable Parliamentary time on the latter would be the better option.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban non biodegradable chewing/bubble gum from being sold in the UK
attributes.background: 374 Billion sticks of chewing gum are produced world wide each year. As the majority of these are made from plastic they cause big problems for the environment regardless of if they are thrown on the street or in the bin. Biodegradable alternatives are available and should replace plastic gum.
attributes.additional_details: I would like the government to ban the sale of chewing / bubble gum that contains plastic - forcing big brands to change their products and allowing the UK to clean up it's streets. It is estimated that it costs councils £60million a year to remove chewing gum from the streets of the UK - this is money that should and could easily be used elsewhere.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Don't close zoos, wildlife parks & rehabilitation centres.
attributes.background: In light of newly considerations re tighter national rules to combat COVID, I urge the government not to consider the closure of zoos, wildlife parks and rehabiltation centres, unless there is verifiable effidence that imcreased infections are linked to visits of such venues.
attributes.additional_details: Zoos, wildlife parks and rehabilitation centres have taken a significant financial impact that is still threatening the continuation of these businesses. These places provide vital contributions to maintain our natural environment, to prevent the extinction of endangered species, to help injured wildlife and educate about our natural world, on which we all rely. Their closure may lead to the death of animals and the loss of many jobs.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Place large environmental taxes on the use of private jets
attributes.background: Hefty environmental taxes should be placed on those who decide to pollute the environment for no good reason but too show off wealth, power and status. These extra taxes can then be used to inject cash into new technologies and infrastructures to reach our target of being carbon neutral by 2050
attributes.additional_details: These small steps going to have to be implemented quickly and effectively to have any chance of combatting climate change and it consequences.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Allow free parking for all NHS employees on NHS property or their place of work.
attributes.background: Ensure that all NHS trusts are obligated to negotiate future and renegotiate current contracts to ensure free parking for NHS employees at all NHS or contracted out car parks in the UK, and to prevent NHS employees being charged to park their cars at their place of work.
attributes.additional_details: Coronavirus has emphasised beyond any doubt, the dedication that NHS employees have always shown in responding to health crises in a working environment where they have also been reluctant to take, or relinquished the right to take industrial action to express grievances, leaving them vulnerable to the type of exploitation of having to pay to be able to attend their place of work.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Trial allowing fans back into stadiums once lockdown ends
attributes.background: The Government should allow trials to take place to show how some fans can attend football matches at all levels of the game within the UK. Football needs the chance of letting fans back into stadiums. Fans must be allowed to return to stadiums in a Covid-secure environment.
attributes.additional_details: Football is more than just a game of tribal loyalty. It’s a game that allows family members to bond, new friendships to be created and local business to thrive on a buzzing match day. The 2012 London Olympics was about creating a legacy for participation in sport, which up until now has been booming. The future of football is at risk. A plan on getting fans back to the stadiums at all levels is needed. I ask football fans within the country for support on the petition. Football needs a chance.

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Mandatory Mental Health Training for all educational and early years staff
attributes.background: We ask the Government to make mental health training mandatory for all educational and early years staff from nursery schools through to universities. All staff in the education services should be trained to identify mental health issues, and also signpost students to relevant support networks.
attributes.additional_details:
A study by Harvard University in 2012 reported that the environment of learning of which a child develops needs to have a level of robust psychological and mental health awareness:
https://46y5eh11fhgw3ve3ytpwxt9r-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/05/Establishing-a-Level-Foundation-for-Life-Mental-Health-Begins-in-Early-Childhood.pdf
 
Mandatory training should help aid early detection of poor mental health in children/adolescents and parents and carers. It can provide further opportunities for early intervention and support. Enabling confidence in people working directly with young people to be able to sign post to support services.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Provide additional funding for collection of roadside rubbish in England
attributes.background: Cleaning up a nation's roadside rubbish is not a task a single person (or group of people) can do and we are therefore calling on the UK Government to take action, and provide additional funding to local authorities and Highways England for collection of roadside rubbish.
attributes.additional_details:
We need the Gov's help because:
 
- The negative impact litter has on the environment
- This problem requires a national solution
- No one likes to live like this, we're a nation that has national pride, let's clean it up!

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Establish a permanent UK climate citizens assembly
attributes.background: There is a need for the Government and Parliament to have a PERMANENT climate citizens assembly to bring together citizens of the public to allow them to express their views and what they feel is acceptable for them and allowing them to be involved with decision making to achieve net zero by 2050.
attributes.additional_details: This would make decision making much more efficient for the Government and Parliament and easier to be accepted by the public. The reason why I feel it would be much more efficient because there is a lack of public trust in the Government and Parliament .With our ever changing environment Assembly members are from all walks of life with no political agenda helping to lay down the foundations for decisions to be made, I feel it would have a better public acceptance and understanding .

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Require specified levels of hedge planting for all new developments
attributes.background: Please set statutory requirements for every building erected and green/brown site built on, or cemented that sufficient hedging is planted for wildlife.
attributes.additional_details:
Developers are tearing down our environment at a great rate of knots.
Please write into constitutional law that all builders and developers MUST combat climate change by hedge (and/or) tree planting. They are quite happy to dodge loopholes on building local amenities i.e. schools by subcontracting, many have no social conscience. If you could please put in law that for every acre they decimate they must replant a portion of greenery to protect humans and wildlife from weathering and erosion, you do us all a favour. No trees, high winds. No food chain, issues.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Establish a presumption against felling of mature trees in England
attributes.background: We are losing native broadleaf trees at a tremendous rate. Felling can have massive impact on wildlife, biodiversity, environment, wellbeing and ultimately climate, yet few trees have Tree Preservation Orders, and there is little policy protection for the remainder.
attributes.additional_details: Policy needs to protect our tree resource and slow the decline of canopy cover. There is little point planting new trees if we continue cutting down mature trees. Young transplants cannot ‘replace’ the canopy of a single hundred-year old oak, and cannot provide significant benefit for years. How much simpler and more effective to retain existing habitats. A licence should be required for the felling of any mature tree, and be granted only in exceptional and clearly defined circumstances.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the use of plastic food packaging
attributes.background: Please take away this option for companies to choose profit over the environment. The Government should ban all plastic food packaging. This can be done over a number of years with support for businesses during a transition period.
attributes.additional_details:
Many of us are trying hard to reduce the amount of plastic waste we’re producing.
Companies don’t make this easier when they bring a new product to market that still uses plastic.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Covid-secure certification to allow businesses to open during lockdowns
attributes.background: The Government should create a system to allow all shops, particularly small independent businesses, to apply for a covid-secure certificate that allows them to stay open during the current and any future lockdowns. Local authorities could conduct spot checks to ensure businesses are opening safely.
attributes.additional_details: Independent business owners keep our businesses covid secure because we care about keeping our customers, ourselves and our families, safe. We should be allowed to open if we offer a secure, clean environment.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban zoos and only permit wildlife sanctuaries that protect animal species
attributes.background: Animal species should be protected, not exploited. Animals should be safe and happy in sanctuaries, not zoos. The Government should ban zoos, and only permit wildlife sanctuaries, with higher animal welfare standards. This should result in more wildlife sanctuaries, with better habitats for animals.
attributes.additional_details: Animals are exploited for money and entertainment. They should be kept safe and happy with space to roam and live as they please, not showcased in a cage. Animals need space to live and should be given that. We believe animals in some zoos are not cared for adequately, and others are simply unhappy. Animals deserve to live in environments more similar to their natural habitats. We don't like isolation, why would they?

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Petition to ban the sale of all non-biodegradable face wipes
attributes.background: Ban the sale of non-biodegradable face wipes
attributes.additional_details: They are very bad for the environment, there are now freely available non-biodegradable wipes on sale to the general public so these could easily be used instead. This would be a small step to helping the environment

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Allow hemp to be used for more than "industrial use of the seed and fibre"
attributes.background: Change the controlled drug domestic license for hemp to allow all uses and not just "industrial use of the seed and fibre". This includes but is not limited to: extraction and distillation of CBD oils, tinctures and concentrates, bio and cooking oils, building materials, textiles and fabrics.
attributes.additional_details:
The current rules regarding the production and use of the industrial hemp plant are outdated.
 
Our country could benefit so much more from the many uses of the plant, including helping reduce our current carbon footprint and helping to alleviate sleep and eating disorders, anxiety, depression, stress and minor muscle and joint pain.
 
We believe the benefits to the environment, construction industry and the overall health and wellbeing of our country will improve if only we are given the chance.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Specialist Cleaners to be added as Critical or Key Workers COVID-19 pandemic
attributes.background: Specialist Cleaning Staff Must be Considered as essential Critical or Key Workers to help with the COVID-19 pandemic who are needed more than ever to ensure we not only maintain but elevate hygiene standards in the UK in order to come out of this crisis quicker.
attributes.additional_details: Specialist cleaners have the staff, products, training, equipment and machinery to reduce the risk to human health by providing & maintaining clean, sanitised and safe premises and environments to help with the prevention of spreading this silent killer.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Create charge for use of non-biodegradable material
attributes.background: Single use plastic, particularly in the food industry, is having a detrimental impact on the environment. Parliament should make a law that requires businesses to charge for these products if customers require single use plastic products (such as plastic straws) made from non-biodegradable material.
attributes.additional_details: In 2015 it was made law in the UK that large retailers could charge 5p for the requirement of plastic bags. Climate change and the impact of single use plastics is a topic which is always on the public agenda for discussion in the UK. We would like to see a progressive approach to the law in this area and therefore we would like to gain support for a charge for all single use plastics.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Make it illegal to manufacture or sell products using non-recyclable plastic
attributes.background: I want to see a safe sustainable future, but man-made products such as plastic are causing enormous damage to the environment. While many products now use recycled plastic a large amount of products contains virgin plastic which uses oil.
attributes.additional_details: By reducing the amount of oil we use we be able to reduce damage to the environment. To help achieve this the Government should ban the manufacture and sale of products using non-recyclable plastic. All companies will need to use recycled plastic in their products. This will help because recycling is helping the environment.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Make the wearing of face masks mandatory in Retail and Workplace settings
attributes.background: For it to be made compulsory for all people to wear face masks in shops and workplaces to reduce the risk of coronavirus (COVID-19) in such areas.
attributes.additional_details: Many workplaces are denying their staff from wearing face masks. This is especially a problem in retail environments. Making face masks mandatory in these settings for employees and customers could reduce risk of coronavirus (COVID-19) spreading among employees, clients and shoppers.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Require a licence to purchase/install bird spikes and netting
attributes.background: Bird spikes and netting have proliferated across buildings, trees and hedges in recent years. This has coincided with significant declines in bird populations as urban areas become ever more inhospitable to birds. We want the sale/installation of these barriers banned, except where licensed.
attributes.additional_details: House Sparrow, House Martin, Swift, Swallow, Starling, Herring Gull and other bird species associated with urban environments have undergone catastrophic population declines in recent decades. We believe the widespread introduction of physical barriers to nesting and roosting have contributed to these unsustainable declines. There are also animal welfare concerns, as birds can become trapped and die in nets. In those cases where the use of such technology can be justified a Government licensing should operate.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale of rabbit cages under 8 square feet
attributes.background: Under the Animal Welfare Act 2006, owners of rabbits must make sure they meet their needs, including providing a suitable environment and place to live. Yet pet shops sell numerous cages that we believe are not adequate. This encourages improper care & threatens the animals welfare.
attributes.additional_details:
Pet shops in the UK advertise many rabbit cages which are under 8 sq ft, and we believe do not meet the required size for the well-being of the animals. Cages from as little as 4.6 sq ft are sold as a suitable home.
 
Many consumers trust pet shops to be advertising correct care information for the well-being of their pet. It is the law to meet the rabbits welfare needs and by selling these cages, we believe pet shops are failing to ensure that the welfare of rabbits is protected.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Include bicycle proficiency in UK school physical education curriculum.
attributes.background:
Physical Education educators to have training in Bikeability (BA), or schools to seek BA instructors, as part of curriculum.
Provide training to primary and secondary school students on safety, the highway code and bicycle use. Action local authorities to assign budget to this.
attributes.additional_details:
With an greater number of road users, particularly those on bicycles, it gives an essential understanding of safety for all using the current infrastructure. 
This will promote safer transport in dense urban environments while reducing carbon emissions and boosting the economy. 
More education will improve commuter experience through confidence, while also addressing national health issues as more children and their parents begin to cycle.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Increase Taxes on Animal Products and Fund Vegan Groups and Animal Charities
attributes.background: Every year, 77 billion land animals are slaughtered for their meat worldwide. 1.2 billion of these are killed in the UK.
attributes.additional_details:
The UK Government must take more action on this issue, and start by increasing taxes on animal products and increasing funding for vegan and animal rights groups and charities
 
Animals are confined and killed in the meat, dairy, egg, honey and fish industries. Also, agriculture is responsible for around 10% of the UK's greenhouse gas emissions.
 
Much of the Amazon rainforest has already been destroyed for cattle ranching. Although growing soya can also be bad for the environment, most of the soya grown is fed to farm animals.
 
Going vegan can also have health benefits, which could help remove strain on the NHS if more heavily promoted or forced.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Make it easier for people to build low impact housing
attributes.background: Update planning laws to allow for environmentally friendly, low impact and sustainable homes to be built in England more easily, thus letting people live with less impact on the environment. This has been done with the one planet development policy in Wales and the crofting legislation in Scotland.
attributes.additional_details: The current housing crisis and worsening climate crisis are both problems facing us currently. The movement for low impact and sustainable dwellings, like those allowed by the Welsh one planet development policy and Scottish Crofting Commission are helping to reduce both of these issues. The current, outdated legislation in England makes it difficult to build low impact dwellings with sustainable materials, ultimately resulting in environmental damage and a potentiation of the housing crisis

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Bring forward and strengthen Biodiversity Net Gain requirements on developments
attributes.background:
Bring forward 10% Mandatory Biodiversity Net Gain requirements on all new housing developments to February 2023. Ensure that all BNG, equalling the minimum 10% net gain, are within the site of development.

The 10% BNG improvements should not be achieved using any off-site habitat enhancements.
attributes.additional_details:
The current 2 year implementation period for the 10% mandatory BNG is too long. We ask that the Government reduce this period in order to protect our fragile environment now.

We are asking for the implementation period to be shortened from 2 years to 16 months meaning it would come into force by the 9th February 2023.

As the Government is aware we are in a climate emergency, we do not have time to allow our environment to be damaged by poor regard to BNG targets which are already recommended.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Work internationally to create fully digital animal export/import certification
attributes.background: The Government should work with other countries, particularly the EU, to create an entirely digital animal export/import certification system. Since Brexit, movement of animals in and out of the UK has become a long, expensive, prone to error process, confusing and unnecessarily expensive.
attributes.additional_details:
Certain documents which need to be exported with the animal require from 9 to 27 pages, and hence it’s not environment friendly either. This could all be avoided using an online certification system.

Establish an online certification system that permanently removes the need for physical paper documents to travel with the animal.

This could make exporters, vets, owners and govt workload slimmer and less prone to errors in the documentation.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Place large environmental taxes on the use of private jets
attributes.background: Hefty environmental taxes should be placed on those who decide to pollute the environment for no good reason but too show off wealth, power and status. These extra taxes can then be used to inject cash into new technologies and infrastructures to reach our target of being carbon neutral by 2050
attributes.additional_details: These small steps going to have to be implemented quickly and effectively to have any chance of combatting climate change and it consequences.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Address concerns of UCL/UL review into the quality of homes through PDR
attributes.background: There are many people living in unfit environments today due to change of use rules under Permitted Development Rights (PDR). This petition is asking for the Government to take action to ensure that such unfortunate conditions are addressed.
attributes.additional_details:
Recently, we've all been having to spend time at home. This has been a challenge for many, but hellish for those whose homes are not up to standard.

A recent study by University College London (UCL) and the University of London (UL) found that homes delivered through change of use PDR were often poorer than those delivered through a full planning permission in terms of delivery of space standards, adequacy of natural light, and access to amenity space, to name a few.

The Government should take action to ensure that homes delivered under change of use PDR are of a comparable standard to those delivered through full planning permission.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Make bikes and bicycle accessories zero-rated for VAT
attributes.background: The Government should zero-rate VAT for pedal cycles and bicycle accessories such as bike helmets, locks and lights.
attributes.additional_details: Pedal cycles, including bicycles, tricycles, tandems, etc should be zero- rated for VAT. This would reduce the cost for users, thereby encouraging their uptake and use, which should benefit the population by encouraging exercise, and the environment by reducing pollution. This should also enable social distancing and reduce reliance on public transport during the Covid-19 outbreak.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Study impact of home working on health & the environment and act on the results
attributes.background:
Business as usual on Earth is unsustainable. Let's learn from CV-19.

We ask the government to a) commission a study into the impacts of home working on the UK during COVID-19 and b) if the findings support it, incentivise employers to enable home working where possible.
attributes.additional_details:
A study would assess whether:

- commuter congestion, stress, collisions, delays & emissions have reduced
- car fuel costs to households have fallen
- worker productivity has increased (from lower stress; working hours that suit the body clock; saved commuting time) 
- work life balance & health is better (e.g taking better breaks, more time for self-care)

The study should examine how potential drawbacks (e.g. increased home expenses, & mental health impacts from less human interaction) can be solved.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Fund a national forest in remembrance of lives lost to the covid 19 virus.
attributes.background: Many UK citizens are personally touched by the loss of life due to covid 19, many of whom have been unable to grieve e.g. attend a funeral, or say farewell to a loved one. Many are left alone dealing with an intangible loss and no support. A tree signifies life/regrowth and is a living tribute.
attributes.additional_details: Planting a forest is a positive action both in terms of improving our environment and creating a landscape through which citizens can walk and exercise. We could create a national forest or localised woodlands as spaces of remembrance and hope. We need something tangible to pay tribute to lost lives - so victims are never forgotten. And the forest/woodland could be used as a platform to educate citizens about habits to maintain good health in the future and how to respect nature.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Prioritise blind and partially sighted for Covid-19 vaccination
attributes.background: We want the government to include blind and partially sighted people in the priority list.
attributes.additional_details:
Blind and partially sighted people face unique challenges which affect independence and everyday life.

People find it difficult/ impossible to judge how far they are from others which is essential for social distancing

They’re in need of support to navigate unfamiliar environments, they will be guided, holding their guiders elbow who will talk to the person and give information about immediate hazards

They are also more likely to use touch to navigate the world around them.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Require recycling systems in NHS clinical areas for plastic healthcare waste
attributes.background: Across the NHS, there are no means of sustainably disposing of uncontaminated plastic clinical waste (namely sterile packaging). This means that huge quantities of potentially recyclable plastic are disposed of daily and sent to landfills or incinerators, greatly harming our environment.
attributes.additional_details: There are no formal recycling plans or mechanisms in place across NHS clinical environments, which we believe is wholly unsustainable. We want to have this changed and for recycling to be the new norm when it comes to uncontaminated clinical and non-clinical waste in the healthcare industry. See www.recycle-health.org”

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Ban the use of lead weights in fresh water fishing
attributes.background: Ban the use of lead weights in fresh water fishing, making companies accountable for products that are non-toxic.
attributes.additional_details:
Lead weights can be damaging to the environment & there were talks of banning leads. This is because in the event of your line snapping or as some promote the ‘drop the lead to protect and catch a fish’ approach, these are then left at the bottom of the water.

This can be harmful to the water, and it’s a well-known fact that some birds drive down picking up stones (lead by mistake) swallow to help break down food in there stomach which in turn their acid will break down the lead poisoning the bird. There have been studies found showing the increase over time in the levels of lead in the blood of both birds & fish in areas of highly fished waters.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Fund free self-defence classes for women in the UK
attributes.background: We want the government to fund free self-defence classes for women and girls throughout communities in the U.K. The government needs to prioritize the health and safety of women for future generations, protecting them from potentially dangerous situations.
attributes.additional_details: It is clear that women within this country are vulnerable to danger, and our safety is not always assured. Teaching women and young girls the skill of protecting themselves and disarming a potential threat not only helps give them the right to feel safe in a threatening environment but equipping them to defend the health and well-being of oneself from harm, and what could be the difference between life and death.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Ban all fishing in UK waters, except rod and line, for 5 years.
attributes.background: Recognise the importance of life in our oceans as critical to our own survival on land. Defend our natural environment and thus society, from collapse. Ban all net fishing vessels from UK waters. Furlough fisherman. Review fishing and labelling standards. Finance independent surveys on fish stocks.
attributes.additional_details:
We need drastic change now, supported by the Government and the Navy, to protect UK waters from all commercial fishing and pollution. Maybe even ban fish from being sold in the UK for 5 years too. We need to protect all ocean life to ensure the future survival of all species, which includes humans. 

The time for drastic action is now. The consequences of inaction will be absolute.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: End all forms of financial support for fossil fuels
attributes.background: A 2019 report by the European Commission found that in 2016 the UK provided over £10 billion in financial support to fossil fuels.
attributes.additional_details: Given the evidence of the impact of carbon emissions on the climate and environment, the Government should end all forms of financial support for fossil fuels.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Ban the use of smartphones in the House of Commons chamber
attributes.background: MPs have long been told not to read newspapers of books in the House of Commons chamber, but MPs are frequently on their mobile phones. We want the use of smartpones in the chamber to be banned. No message is so urgent that a note being passed by a House of Commons official won’t do.
attributes.additional_details: Voters have the right to expect their elected members are focused and concentrating on the matter at hand. I know of no business environment that tolerates people scrolling through their phones during a meeting. It is also unseemly when sessions are televised to see dozens of members peering at their phones, often apparently oblivious to the proceedings.

departments.name: Office of the Leader of the House of Commons

attributes.action: Require packaging that clearly details the environmental impact of products.
attributes.background: Food packaging has nutritional information on the front, using a traffic light system. In a similar way, details such as mean equivalent carbon emissions, land use, water use, ecological impact and resulting pollution should be clearly visible on the front of consumer goods packaging.
attributes.additional_details: Around 26% of global emissions come from food. Most individuals don't have the time to research the environmental impact of their consumables. Implementing this policy will help consumers make more environmentally friendly choices and put pressure on companies to develop products that are better for the planet. In addition, the need for companies to assess environmental impact will result in a boom of jobs in the environment sector. Britain will lead the world in enabling green consumer choices.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Raise national speed limit to 80 mph on motorways and dual carriageways
attributes.background: I want the speed limit to raise to 80 mph on the specified types of roads mentioned, because this will improve road safety, because at the moment there are too many people tailgating each other so therefore raising the speed limit could make people drive more smoothly with less tailgating.
attributes.additional_details: This could raise the UK productivity as people can go to destinations quicker and therefore reducing the risk of an accident. There is alot of tailgating caused by slow moving vehicles raising peoples stress levels and increasing the risk of an accident  which is why there are more road deaths which some could have been better prevented. This is a fast moving environment with days getting more busy so the speed limit needs to be raised to meet the demands of ever fast changing world we live in.

departments.name: Department for International Trade

attributes.action: Ban Unpaid Internships lasting longer than 4 weeks
attributes.background: There is currently an environment where many students feel pressured to undertake internships. Employers have exploited this demand for experience by offering unpaid opportunities. This can benefit privileged graduates while leaving behind the less fortunate to fend for themselves.
attributes.additional_details: This problem requires, real, sensitive attention. The Sutton Trust have found that there is a very real gap between the opportunities and future employment prospects between middle and lower classes, and interning is a key factor of this. If this Government really is levelling up then they must tackle this problem with some urgency to prevent generation after generation being exploited.
